doc.field: Ford family papers and Long Island Historical Society exhibition records
Ford family papers and Long Island Historical Society exhibition records

Assembled for a 1974 Long Island Historical Society (known today as Brooklyn Historical Society) exhibition, the collection contains papers and photographs relating to the Ford family. The Fords were one of the most productive literary families living in the Brooklyn Heights neighborhood of Brooklyn in the latter part of the 19th century. The bulk of the collection are 20th century fascimiles of original papers, the content of which dates back to the 1850s. The collection includes numerous portraits of the Ford family, as well as one ledger from an unidentified Brooklyn school (1870s).

Assembled for a 1974 Long Island Historical Society (known today as Brooklyn Historical Society) exhibition, the collection contains papers and photographs relating to the Ford family. The Fords were one of the most productive literary families living in the Brooklyn Heights neighborhood of Brooklyn in the latter part of the 19th century. The bulk of the collection are 20th century fascimiles of original papers, the content of which dates back to the 1850s. The collection includes numerous portraits of the Ford family, as well as one ledger from an unidentified Brooklyn school (1870s).

Assembled for a 1974 Long Island Historical Society (known today as Brooklyn Historical Society) exhibition, the collection contains papers and photographs relating to the Ford family. The bulk of the collection consists of 20th century fascimiles of original papers, the content of which dates back to the 1850s.

The papers include biographical pieces on various members of the Ford family, as well as correspondence, clippings, and writings. The collection includes numerous portraits of the Ford family, dating from circa 1850s to the 1920s. Some of these portraits include the interior of the Ford family residence, which was located at 97 Clark Street in the Brooklyn Heights neighborhood of Brooklyn. Exhibition records included in the collection consist of oversize clippings and a press release announcing the opening of "The Fords of Clark Street" exhibition.

The collection also contains one ledger from an unidentified Brooklyn school. The ledger contains listings of students, with their date of admission, parents' names, residence, class number, teacher's name, and date of dismissal. The students all appear to have lived in the Cobble Hill and Carroll Gardens neighborhoods of Brooklyn. The ledger dates from 1869 to 1874.

The Fords were one of the most productive literary families living in the Brooklyn Heights neighborhood of Brooklyn in the latter part of the 19th century. Emily, the mother, was a minor poet. Paul Leicester, first-born son, was a famous novelist, biographer and bibliographer. Another son, Worthington Chauncey, produced dozens of historical works and was editor of the multi-volume Writings of George Washington. Malcolm, a third son, was an athlete of Olympic stature who was also a sportswriter.
- Long Island Historical Society press release for an exhibition entitled "The Fords of Clark Street" (1974)
Papers and photographs were the gift of Ellsworth N. Bailey, 1978. Exhibition material produced by Long Island Historical Society, 1974.
Brooklyn Historical Society (Brooklyn, New York, N.Y.)
